instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has voltage but no CPU
threads.message: This had some type of minor spill but I'm struggling to find much sign of it. The little bit of corrosion was cleaned before it got to me. It gets 20V, has <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, has 5V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_MAIN_VCCSA</SIGNAL> but no CPU power. There is a very slight amount of heat on the CPU. I'm not finding any shorts though. Any idea where to go next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has voltage but no CPU
threads.message: Post voltage for all big coils...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has voltage but no CPU
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has voltage but no CPU
threads.message:
VCCGT appears only under grapichs load.

You could have a dead CPU now, if someone reflowed it before.
Check powers and enable signal for CPU power supply.
Be sure DDR power supply works too, as other voltages which are not on coils; Power FETs, page 78.
You can also try full new BIOS; not only clean ME of your board.
